hints.content:
There are $\purpleC7$ kids in each group.

There are $\greenD{56}$ total kids.

[[☃ image 1]]



How many $\blueD{\text{groups}}$ are there?

options.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of unequal lengths, a first tape labeled 56 and a shorter second tape with one part labeled 7. A curved bracket across the bottom and the width of the first tape is labeled with a question mark and the words equal groups. !

hints.content:
We can write this as a multiplication problem. 

$\purpleC{\text{size of the group}}\times\blueD{\text{ number of groups}} = \greenD{\text{ total}}$

So, $\purpleC7\times\blueD{\text{?}} = \greenD{56}$

We can also write this as a division problem. 

$\greenD{\text{total}}\div\purpleC{\text{ size of the groups}}=\blueD{\text{ number of groups}} $

So, $\greenD{56}\div \purpleC7=\blueD{\text{?}}$

The equations that would help us find out how many groups of kids are at magic camp are:  

 -   $\purpleC7\times\blueD{\text{?}} = \greenD{56}$
 - $\greenD{56}\div \purpleC7=\blueD{\text{?}}$

question.content:
Every group at magic camp is made up of $7$ kids.  There are $56$ total kids at magic camp.


**Which equations would help us find out how many groups of kids are at magic camp?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
